Items.Title: Roll Call
Invocation
Items.AgendaNote:
Delivered by: Rev. Julie Taylor, Executive Director, Disaster Chaplaincy Services, 520 Eighth Avenue, New York, NY 10018.

Motion to spread the invocation in full upon the record by Council Member Jackson.
Items.MinutesNote:
The Invocation was delivered by Rev. Julie Taylor, Executive Director, Disaster Chaplaincy Services, 520 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018.

Council Member Jackson moved to spread the Invocation in full upon the Record.

Items.Title: Adoption of Minutes
Items.AgendaNote: Motion that the Minutes of the Stated Meetings of January 30 and February 13, 2008 be adopted as printed by Council Member Gentile.
Items.MinutesNote: Council Member Gentile moved that the Minutes of the Stated Meeting of January 30, 2008 and February 13, 2008 be adopted as printed.

Items.Title: Messages & Papers from the Mayor

Communication from the Mayor - Mayors veto and disapproval message of Introductory Number 61-A, in relation to prohibiting landlords from discriminating against tenants based on lawful source of income.
Items.ActionText: This Mayor's Message was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on General Welfare
Items.MatterName: Prohibiting landlords to discriminate against tenants based on lawful source of income.

Items.Title: Petitions and Communications
Land Use Call-Ups

By The Speaker (Council Member Quinn):
Pursuant to Rule 11.20(b) of the Council and Section 20-226(g) of the New York City Administrative Code, the Council resolves that the action of the Department of Consumer Affairs approving an unenclosed sidewalk café located at 184 Spring Street, Application no. 20055291 TCM shall be subject to review by the Council.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Land Use Call-Up be Approved, by Council approved by Roll Call.
Items.MatterName: Sidewalk Cafe, Emilia, Inc. d.b.a. L’Ulivo, Manhattan (20055291TCM)

Items.Title: Report of the Committee on Parks and Recreation

A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the city of New York to prune trees, bushes and other vegetation that obstruct traffic control signals or devices.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Introduction be Approved by Council approved by consent Roll Call.
Items.MatterName: Requiring the city of New York to prune trees that block traffic signs or signals within three days of notification.

Items.MatterName: Requiring the department of transportation to conduct studies of traffic accident locations

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the United States Congress to pass S.1065/H.R.3051, also known as The Heroes at Home Act.
Items.AgendaNote: Adopted by the Committee on Veterans
Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, the Public Advocate (Ms. Gotbaum) called for a voice vote.  Hearing no objections, the Public Advocate (Ms. Gotbaum) declared the Resolution to be adopted.

Adopted unanimously by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Resolution be Approved, by Council approved by Voice Vote.
Items.MatterName: Congress to pass S.1065/H.R.3051, also known as The Heroes at Home Act.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the United States Congress to pass as the “Bridging the Gap for Wounded Warriors Act”.
Items.AgendaNote: Adopted by the Committee on Veterans
Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, the Public Advocate (Ms. Gotbaum) called for a voice vote.  Hearing no objections, the Public Advocate (Ms. Gotbaum) declared the Resolution to be adopted.

Adopted unanimously by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Resolution be Approved, by Council approved by Voice Vote.
Items.MatterName: Congress to pass as the “Bridging the Gap for Wounded Warriors Act”.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the United States Congress to pass S.1113/H.R.2048, also known as the “Traumatic Brain Injury Access to Options Act.”
Items.AgendaNote: Adopted by the Committee on Veterans
Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, the Public Advocate (Ms. Gotbaum) called for a voice vote.  Hearing no objections, the Public Advocate (Ms. Gotbaum) declared the Resolution to be adopted.    

Adopted unanimously by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Resolution be Approved, by Council approved by Voice Vote.
Items.MatterName: Traumatic Brain Injury Access to Options Act.

INTRODUCTION AND READING OF BILLS
A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to adjusting traffic signal timing in areas with high concentrations of seniors.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation
Items.MatterName: Adjusting traffic signal timing in areas with high concentrations of seniors.

Items.Title: Resolution calling for the removal of the 2008 Olympic Games from Beijing and calling upon all American businesses and corporations who have their headquarters in New York City or do business in New York City to review their financial dealings with China to ensure compliance with international human rights standards, and to withdraw sponsorship or support of the 2008 Olympic Games if they are held in China.
Items.AgendaNote: Cultural Affairs, Libraries & International Intergroup Relations
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Cultural Affairs, Libraries and International Intergroup Relations
Items.MatterName: Removal of the 2008 Olympic Games from Beijing.

Items.Title: State Legislation Resolution requesting the New York State Legislature to pass bills introduced by Senator Lanza, S.3274-A, and Assembly Member Lentol, A.5055-A, “AN ACT to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to extending the benefits of the variable supplements fund for housing police and transit police members of the New York city employees’ retirement system”.
Items.ActionText: This SLR was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on State and Federal Legislation
Items.MatterName: Extending benefits of the variable supplements fund (S.3274-A, A.5055-A).

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to creating a civil cause of action for certain intimate partner victims of domestic violence.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Public Safety
Items.MatterName: Creating a civil cause of action for certain intimate partner victims of domestic violence.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the sale of tickets to individual consumers by operators of theater, music, or sporting events taking place in New York City at places of entertainment.

Items.MatterName: Relation to the sale of tickets to individual consumers by operators of theater, music, or sporting events taking place in NYC at places of entertainment that receive public funding.

Items.MatterName: Electronic equipment collection standards.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the Mayor to submit an Executive Budget for fiscal year 2009 that restores proposed cuts to the Department of Education budget, including the $324 million announced in January and any additional 3% (estimated to exceed $200 million) announced in March, and to immediately reverse the $180 million in recently enacted mid-year school budget cuts.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Finance
Items.MatterName: Mayor to submit an Executive Budget for fiscal year 2009 that restores proposed cuts to the Department of Education budget.

Items.Title: Resolution finding that the enactment of Preconsidered Int. No. 729 does not have a significant adverse impact on the environment and is consistent with The State Environmental Quality Review Act.

Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Sanitation and Solid Waste Management
Items.MatterName: Electronic equipment collection standards.

Items.MatterName: Recycling, reuse and safe handling of electronic equipment sold in NYC.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the city of New York to repair any sidewalk damaged by a tree under its exclusive care.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation
Items.MatterName: Requiring the city of New York to repair any sidewalk damaged by a tree under its exclusive care.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to identifying, eliminating and preventing discrimination, and promoting human rights in governmental operations.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Civil Rights
Items.MatterName: Identifying, eliminating and preventing discrimination, and promoting human rights in governmental operations.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York State Legislature to pass, and the Governor to sign, legislation which would extend the allowance of a clean heating fuel tax credit.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Finance
Items.MatterName: Extend the allowance of a clean heating fuel tax credit.

Items.Title: Resolution denouncing the current starting salaries for police officers of the New York City Police Department.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Public Safety
Items.MatterName: Denouncing the current starting salaries for police officers of the NYPD.

Items.Title: Resolution calling on the New York State Legislature to pass  A. 7213-A/S. 5375-A, an act to amend the Administrative Code of the City of New York, in relation to allowing members of the Police Department to remain in service until age 65.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Public Safety
Items.MatterName: Allowing members of the Police Department to remain in service until age 65.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to unlock doors between cars on New York City subway trains.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation
Items.MatterName: MTA to unlock doors between cars on New York City subway trains.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York City Comptroller to set up a decency commission to analyze New York City pension investments in record labels that release offensive materials.

Items.MatterName: Comptroller to set up a decency commission to analyze NYC pension investments in record labels that release offensive materials.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the New York city charter and administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to enacting the New York city fire code, and repealing subdivisions (7) through (19) of section 15-232 and chapter 4 of title 27 of the administrative code, relating to the New York city fire prevention code.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Fire and Criminal Justice Services
Items.MatterName: Enacting the NYC fire code, and repealing subdivisions (7) through (19) of section 15-232 and chapter 4 of title 27 of the administrative code, relating to the NYC fire prevention code.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring contractors entering into arrangements with the city for housing development to pay the prevailing wage to their employees who perform work under such arrangements.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Contracts
Items.MatterName: Requiring contractors entering into arrangements with the city for housing development to pay the prevailing wage to their employees who perform work under such arrangements.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York City Housing Authority to allow the City-Wide Task Force on Housing Court to set up an assistance table for the benefit of unrepresented residents outside NYCHA housing administrative tribunal hearings.

Items.MatterName: City-Wide Task Force on Housing Court to set up an assistance table for the benefit of unrepresented residents outside NYCHA housing administrative tribunal hearings.

Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Public Safety
Items.MatterName: Repeal or amend the present Rockefeller Drug Laws.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the New York city charter, in relation to requiring the New York city department of education to provide certain security measures for nonpublic schools.

Items.MatterName: Requiring the NYC department of education to provide certain security measures for nonpublic schools.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York and the New York city building code, in relation to licensing elevator inspectors.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to elder abuse prevention.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Aging
Items.MatterName: Elder abuse prevention.

Items.Title: A Local Law in relation to the date of submission by the Mayor of the proposed executive budget and budget message, the date of submission by the Borough Presidents of recommendations in response to the Mayor’s executive budget, the date of publication of a report by the director of the independent budget office analyzing the executive budget, the date by which the Council hearings pertaining to the executive budget shall conclude, the date by which if the expense budget has not been adopted, the expense budget and tax rate adopted as modified for the current fiscal year shall be deemed to have been extended for the new fiscal year until such time as a new expense budget has been adopted, the date by which if a capital budget and a capital program have not been adopted, the unutilized portion of all prior capital appropriations shall be deemed reappropriated, the date of submission by the Mayor of an estimate of the probable amount of receipts, the date by which any person or organization may submit an official alternative estimate of revenues, the date by which if the Council has not fixed the tax rates for the ensuing fiscal year, the commissioner of finance shall be authorized to complete the assessment rolls using estimated rates, and related matters, relating to the fiscal year two thousand nine.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Finance
Items.MatterName: Executive Budget Extender

Items.Title: Resolution approving or disclosing the changes in the designation of certain organizations to receive funding in the Fiscal 2008 Expense Budget.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Finance
Items.MatterName: Approving or disclosing the changes in the designation of certain organizations to receive funding in the Fiscal 2008 Expense Budget.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York State Legislature to adopt S.5466 and A.6854, legislation which would amend the Financial Emergency Act (“FEA” or the “Act”) to allow the City of New York to establish a “rainy day” fund, and ensure that any extension of the Act includes provisions for such fund, as well as provisions requiring regular financial reporting by all covered organizations to the Mayor and City Council, making the Act a “Financial Emergency Act for the 21st Century”.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Finance
Items.MatterName: Amend the Financial Emergency Act (“FEA” or the “Act”)

Items.MinutesNote: The Public Advocate (Ms. Gotbaum) put the question whether the Council would agree with and adopt such motion which was decided in the affirmative by the following vote:
